sub_title: Policy Advisor. Migration. Asylum. Human Trafficking. International Crimes.

profile_positions.description: I designed and developed the training programme for multiple groups of new employees who started working as RSD officers in 2018 and 2019. Subsequently, I (in collaboration with a few other colleagues) coördinated the programme by: appointing, supervising and advising trainers/coaches, developing evaluation formats, monitoring quality and progress, organizing and/or giving specific training sessions, liaising with the management team and the staff planners in order to adjust plans/establish new plans and/or arrange various practical matters.
profile_positions.title: Senior Officer

profile_positions.description:
My core responsibilities were to conduct both the initial and detailed interviews and to take and write the formal (intended) decisions on the asylum claims. I also mentored and trained new colleagues to become fully authorised RSD officers.

Moreover, I served as the anti-human trafficking coordinator at my office and as an expert on religion-based asylum claims. As part of the latter two roles I developed and gave workshops and presentations, I provided input and advice on procedures, methods, formats and policies, I advised- and answered questions from- colleagues and I liaised with various internal and external partners concerning working methods as well as individual cases. 

In addition, I acted as an IND spokesperson in the media a couple of times, for example for BBC World and a major radio station in de USA.
profile_positions.title: Refugee Status Determination Officer

profile_positions.description: For years I had dreamed about traveling to South America for a couple of months to immerse myself in the culture and the Spanish language. In august 2019 I finally decided to take the leap and turn this dream into reality. I traveled to Medellin, Colombia where I took Spanish courses at EAFIT University (at B1 and B2 level). Furthermore, I served as a language buddy for inhabitants of Medellin's Comuna 13 (formerly the city's most dangerous neighborhood but nowadays a symbol of it's urban transformation) who were attending free English classes at San Javier Library.
profile_positions.title: Sabbatical/Spanish student

profile_positions.description:
I worked at the consular department of the Embassy of the Netherlands on secondment from the IND. 

During my secondment I conducted interviews with people (mainly Eritreans) who applied for family reunification with family members who had been granted an asylum status in the Netherlands. 

Furthermore, I liaised between the Immigration Services in the Netherlands and the embassy in Ethiopia and answered numerous questions from both sides, I consulted the embassy staff on several complex migration-related cases, I represented the embassy at a meeting with UNHCR and I supported the consular department with all kinds of pratical tasks. Moreover, I wrote a new instruction manual for my successors and I took the initiative to propose a number of improvements regarding procedures, interview formats, instructions and the cooperation between the IND and the embassy. Thus, one of the things I managed to improve was the way in which the transfer between two successive IND employees took place, resulting in a considerable efficiency gain.
profile_positions.title: Consular Officer

profile_positions.description: When I joined the board, the D66 Theme Department on Society Migration and Asylum was largely inactive. During my term and with my input, it developed into a very lively and successful department with approximately 400 members. To this end, we developed a new organizational plan, came up with a new name for the theme department and employed various new activities. As a secretary I was specifically responsible for the meeting minutes and the communication with approximately 400 members of the theme department. Furthermore, I helped to organize discussion sessions, fringe meetings, and symposia on topics such as radicalization, integration and the European migration and asylum crisis. Those meeting were attended by city councilors, members of the national- and European parliament and (up to 500) other members of D66.
profile_positions.title: Board Member (Secretary) of D66 Theme Department on Society, Migration and Asylum

profile_positions.description:
The Young Democrats is a social-liberal political youth organisation. I have been a member of two of its committees. 

Firstly, I was a member of Team Arab Transition, a committee that organized a training conference for political youth in Tunisia. The conference included some high profile speakers and covered topics such as campaigning, political currents and international political cooperation. I was specifically responsible for the communication with our speakers and the mother party D66. In June 2013 I returned to Tunisia as part of a delegation of representatives from different Dutch Political Youth Organizations. The purpose of this trip, organized by the Netherlands Institute for Multiparty Democracy, was to establish relationships with our Tunisian counterparts and to learn from each others experiences. 

Secondly, as a member of the International Committee I organized debate nights on topics such as human trafficking in Amsterdam and the uprisings in the Arab region.
profile_positions.title: Committee member of: Team Arabic Transition and the International Committee

profile_positions.description:
As a (junior) policy advisor for the Democrats 66 (a social- liberal political party) in the Dutch House of Representatives I was part of a cluster of Members of Parliament and policy advisors focusing on policy areas such as Infrastructure, Economics, Finance and Spatial planning.

I was responsible for the substantive preparation of plenary debates and committee meetings for various Members of Parliament on the topics infrastructure (roads) and environment. I also wrote speeches and I wrote and submitted motions and amendments as well as the party's contributions to written consultations. Furthermore I conducted (political) analyses and provided the MPs with strategic advice.

Furthermore, I performed secretarial tasks for my policy cluster, such as the preparation of meetings and answering calls and e-mails from citizens. I also performed some secretarial tasks for one of the MPs in specific, as I helped him prioritize, plan and prepare meetings with lobbyists and representatives of various organizations. I continued to perform these tasks and manage his agenda when this MP became the campaign leader for the 2012 elections.
profile_positions.title: (Junior) Policy Advisor

company.name: Human Rights Education Institute of Burma

profile_positions.company: Human Rights Education Institute of Burma
profile_positions.description:
Human Rights Education Institute of Burma is an NGO that facilitates a broad range of human rights training and advocacy programs for grassroots organizations and community leaders. 

During my internship I worked on a research project led by Asia Against Child Trafficking (Asia ACTs), on the access to justice of child trafficking victims in Thailand, Cambodia and the Philippines. I contributed to the establishment of the research design, performed a literature study, and conducted interviews with NGOs concerned with the protection of victims, such as Save the Children and the Center for the Protection of Children's Rights.

This project resulted in the report "Stories from the field: A Glimpse on Trafficked Children’s Access to Justice in Thailand, Cambodia, and Philippines."

Furthermore, I spent time teaching English to a group of Burmese refugees between the ages of 12 and 18 who came to Chiang Mai to take part in a summer program organized by HREIB to educate them on human rights and improve their English language skills.
profile_positions.title: Intern

profile_positions.description:
With limited resources but a lot of dedication and enthusiasm I built the UNICEF Student Team Maastricht from the ground up. I started by marketing the 'soon to be established' team among students in Maastricht by distributing flyers and posters that were sponsored by local print shops, and by organizing an information meeting in a venue that was made available free of charge by Maastricht University. This way, I managed to recruit an amazing group of volunteers who were eager to start promoting and supporting UNICEF and their important work. Since then, the UNICEF Student Team organized several successful fundraising events and events to educate people (specifically students) about UNICEF and its goals and projects. 

As president of the team I coordinated our events, was responsible for the communication with UNICEF Netherlands and chaired the periodical team meetings. I am proud that my efforts resulted in a team that is nowadays still a very successful and active part of student life in Maastricht and of the UNICEF student network in the Netherlands.
profile_positions.title: Founder and President of the UNICEF Student Team Maastricht

profile_positions.description:
The Commonwealth Human Rights Initiative (CHRI) is an international, independent and non-partisan NGO which works towards the practical realization of human rights in the countries of the Commonwealth.

During my time at CHRI I wrote a research report on the terms of the Electoral Commissioner in Ghana and wrote a part of the organization’s Annual Report of 2008. Furthermore, I participated in a fact-finding mission to Kete Krachi, a rural community in Eastern Ghana, to investigate the situation of trafficked children in their community. Furthermore, we organized an information and discussion meeting for chiefs, local NGOs and other interested people, with the purpose of transferring knowledge and creating awareness on child trafficking and child labor in the respective region.
profile_positions.title: Intern
